characters: "DEL AMO MALL TORRANCE, CALIFORNIA LARGEST INDOOR MALL IN
A YOUNG BLACK COMEDIAN ON TV
WITH ORDELL WAITING OUTSIDE THE DOOR
A YOUNG WOMAN A.T.F SURVEILLANCE AGENT
MAX'S GUN IN ORDELL ORDELL'S CROTCH
BACK TO MAX AT THE MALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the rhythm of funky seventies SOUL MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is JACKIE BROWN, a stewardess dressed in her CABO AIR uniform. (A little shuttle airline that flies from Los Angeles to Cabo San Lucas. Approximate flight time: forty five minutes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie stands still as a people-mover slowly inches her through the airport. The CREDITS APEAR and DISAPPEAR in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie Brown is a very attractive black woman in her mid forties, though she looks like she's in her mid-thirties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people-mover reaches the end of the line, she steps off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She breezes through Customs and we follow her with a STEDICAM as she strides through the airport... She gets to her gate disappears inside the plane for a moment comes back out sans flight bag picks up the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flight 710 Cabo San Lucas, now boarding Gate 12, first class only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a smile on her face, she collects passengers' boarding passes as they board the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chorus line of six beautiful bikini-clad women, all holding different automatic weapons, BLASTING away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One bikini beauty is singled out. She's a gorgeous brunette named SIDNEY. Sidney stands facing camera holding a TEC-9 and describing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Sidney. And I love to TEC-9. The popular TEC-9 is advertised by its makers as being tough as the toughest customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIDNEY'S STATISTICS: Age, height, measurements, date of birth, appear at the bottom left-hand corner. As Sidney continues her sales pitch/demonstration, a BLACK MAN'S VOICE begins talking over the video.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a TEC-9. It's a cheap ass spray gun outta South Miami.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a CLOSEUP of the TEC-9, Sidney FIRES the weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cost three-eighty retail. I get them for two hundred and sell 'em for eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Black Voice belong to forty-five-year old ORDELL ROBBIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell wears clothes nice and likes wearing nice clothes. Stylish, athletic wear (Reebok), heavy, black leather jackets (Hugo Boss), warm-colored berets and baseball caps to cover his balding head are Ordell's "look." At this moment Ordell's wearing an open silk shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell narrates the video playing on the big-screen V. (the most expensive thing in the apartment). He holds a cocktail in one hand (screwdriver, his drink of choice) and the remote control in the other, pacing the floor in his I-can-talk-anybody-into-anything voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS GARA, who looks like he does his shopping at the Salvation Army (dressed in a Hawaiian shirt and dungarees), sits on the sofa staring blankly at the video, drinking Jack Daniels on ice. Louis, white, also in his mid forties, has lived over half of his life in penal institutions. The experience has affected both his body language and his thought process.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While acutely aware of the rhythm of life inside a correction facility, in the real world his timing is thrown. It's like a song he doesn't know the lyrics to but attempt to sing anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The third person watching the video is the person who lives in this apartment, MELANIE RALSTON. Melanie, thirty three, is a tanned, blonde, California beach bunny. Like the kind you se in the old Crown International movies from the seventies like "Pom Pom Girls" "Malibu Beach" and "Beach Girls," except Melanie is older than any of those girls ever are. She's dressed in her Melanie- uniform of stringy Levis cutoffs and a stringy bra top. So far Melanie has been able to make a living out of lying in the sun, always finding a generous, wealthy man more than willing to pay her rent and pick up her tabs. In her prime (twenty two) it was Japanese industrialists, film production guys, and Middle Eastern businessmen who kept Melanie. And it was places like the Bahamas, Acapulco, and the Virgin Islands where they kept her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now, at thirty three, she lives in an apartment in Hermosa Beach, California that Ordell pays for an drops in and out of. She's curled up in a reclining chair, smoking weed from a pipe, reading Movieline Magazine and paying no attention to the video.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This TEC-9? They advertise it as being the most popular gun in American crime. Can you believe that shit? It actually says that on the little booklet that comes with it. "Most Popular Gun in American Crime," like they're proud of that shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell hits the fast-forward on his remote control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney is rushed off the screen and replace by CINDY, a pretty, blonde bodybuilder clad in a red, white and blue bikini, holding a Styer Aug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check out this body-builder chick... Now see what she got. That's a Styer aug. Styer Aug's a bad motherfucker. Listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy BLASTS the Styer Aug, loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell imitates the sound of the weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit's expensive, man. Comes from Austria. My customers don't know shit about it, so there ain't no demand. (to Melanie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, I could use some more ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie puts down the magazine, takes his cocktail glass from him and moves to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But put that bad boy in a flick, every motherfucker out there want one. I'm serious as a heart attack. Them Hong Kong movies came out, every nigga gotta have a forty-five. And they don't want one, they want two, cause nigga want to be "The Killer." What they don't know, and that movie don't tell you is a .45 has a serious fuckin' jammin' problem. I always try and steer a customer towards a 9- millimeter. Damn near the same weapon, don't have half the jammin' problems. But some niggas out there, you can't tell them anything. They want a .45. The killer had a .45, they want a .45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie comes back, hands Ordell his screwdriver, then sits where she was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell sits down on the couch. Melanie's reading "Movieline Inside" magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Walker. He runs a fishing boat in Mexico. I deliver the merchandise to him, gets it to my customers. On all my bulk sales, anyway. Nigga didn't have a pot to piss in or a window to throw it out 'fore I set 'em up. Now, motherfucker's rollin' in cash. He got himself a yacht, with all kinds of high tech navigational shit on it. (back to video)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AK-47, the very best there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GLORIA, a tall, Amazonian, bikini-clad, black woman faces camera and describes the AK-47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you absolutely, positively, gotta kill every motherfucker in the room, accept no substitute. That there is the Chinese one. I pay eight- fifty and double my money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get that for me, will ya baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girl, you better not make me go over there and put my feet to ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis keeps staring at he screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie gets up, goes over to the counter that separates the living room from the kitchen, picks up the phone, says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puts the phone down and says;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Ordell knows it, Melanie is back in the reclining chair, reclining back all the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell, pissed, looks at her a moment before taking the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis sits on he couch, drinking his Jack Daniels, watching the video.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie lies back on the reclining chair, takes a hit off her pipe, then says in a 'holding in smoke' voice;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can sit through it once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks he's Joe Gunn now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm impressed. He knows a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just repeating shit he overheard. He ain't any more a gun expert than I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis takes a hit off the pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you get out of jail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two months shy of four years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis takes a drink of whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four years that's a long fuckin time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis nods his head in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell comes back, sitting down on the other side of Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, what did I tell you? Man in New York wants a 9 millimeter Smith and Wesson Model 5946. Why does he want it? It's the gun that nigga on "New York Undercover" uses. Because of that nigga, I can sell it to this nigga for twelve-fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I been tellin' you. Start adding these motherfuckin' figures up, and you tell me this ain't a business to be in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have a bit of a staring contest before she gets up and gets the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got me five M-60 machine guns. These came straight from the Gulf War. I sold me three of them so far, twenty grand a piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, this is it, man. I'm gonna make me a million dollars out of this. I already got me a half-a- million sittin' in Mexico. When I do this last delivery, I'm gonna make me another half-million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get out. Spend the rest of my life spending.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie sits back down in he chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell, drink in hand, picks up the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck you doin' in jail? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck you doin' that for? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't you got better sense than to be drivin' drunk carrying a goddam pistol?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He listens to Beaumont on the other line - it's obvious Beaumont's starting to freak out. Ordell changes his tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Beaumont. Beaumont. Listen to me. Number one, you need to chill out, nigga. Bad as this shit is, this shit ain't as bad as you think it is. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course you're scared. That's what these motherfuckers get paid for scarin' the shit outta ya. That's their job. And my job is to get you the fuck home so let me tell you what is gonna happen... May I speak?... Thank you... You gonna spend the night in jail; it's too late to get you out now. Tomorrow, they gonna take you into court. I'm gonna be there. Judge gonna set your bail. I'm gonna pay your bail, they gonna cut you loose. By tomorrow night, you'll be back home, I promise. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So just calm your ass down, and I'll see you tomorrow. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You owe me a helluva lot more than one, nigga. (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The store front window of Cherry Bail Bonds in Inglewood, California. The name of the business is spelled out on the window, which also includes a drawing of a fat red cherry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell's BLACK MERCEDES CONVERTIBLE pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell in the driver's seat. Louis in shotgun position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside Cherry Bail Bonds, looking out through the picture window. We can read the name on the glass backwards. Ordell and Louis appears in the window and enter the building. Ordell carries a L.A. Lakers athletic bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An unidentified MALE VOICE, obviously on the telephone, can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell goes toward the voice and tells Louis to "hang back."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the judge doesn't give a fuck about that. He's ready to habitualize you. Is that what you want - you wanna look at ten years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice belong to MAX CHERRY, bail bondsman. Max, a regular-Joe-type white guy in his fifties, sits behind his desk talking on the phone. His eyes raise as he sees Ordell approach him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just overnight is all. Tomorrow I'll get you out, I promise. But it means I gotta pick you up tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell motion to the chair in front of Max's desk. Max motions for Ordell to take a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie, there ain't no two ways about it. You're spending the night in jail, but I already told you I'll get you out tomorrow. Now where are you? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're at your mother's house, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He notices a picture on the wall of Max with his arm around a big, powerfully built black man. They're both grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis pours himself some coffee from a coffeemaker into a small, white styrofoam cup. He picks up a jar of powdered non-dairy creamer that's so dry he has to break off a rock. Louis adds the rock of coffeemate to his beverage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Just stay put till I come for you. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie, do yourself a really big favor and be there when I get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell sits in front of the desk, smiling at him and smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would you like me to put my ash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max looks at him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use that coffee cup on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell picks up the coffee cup, which still has a little bit of coffee in it, and flicks his ash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I need me a bond for ten thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max throws a look past Ordell to Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's just my white friend, Louis. He's got nothing to do with my business. We just hangin together. We're on our way to a cocktail lounge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From across the room, Louis nods his head in Max's direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max looks at him a moment, then back to Ordell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that big Mandingo nigga you gotcha arm around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max looks at him a moment and says;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a big one. You two tight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was our idea to take the picture, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max looks at Ordell, getting his drift, then says;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you want a ten-thousand dollar bond. What've you got for collateral?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna have to put up cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell picks up his Lakers bag and puts it in the empty chair next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have cash. What do you need me for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, you know how they do. Black man comes in with ten thousand, they wanna fuck with 'em. First off, they gonna wanna know where I got it. Second, they gonna keep a big chunk of it - start talkin' that court cost shit. Fuck that shit, Jack. I'll go through you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cost you a thousand for the bond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis just stands, feeling uncomfortable, in the other room drinking coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fella named Beaumont. They have him up at county. It started out drunk driving, but they wrote it up "possession of a concealed weapon." Dumb monkey-ass had a pistol on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ran his name and got a hit. He's been in before. Besides, Beaumont's from Kentucky, and I think they're prejudiced against black men from the South out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes off and I gotta go to Kentucky to bring him back, you pay the expenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you could do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max taking papers out of the drawer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaumont. That's the only name I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max looks at Ordell, but doesn't ask him the obvious question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max on hold, looks at Ordell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, this is Max Cherry. Cherry Bail Bonds. Who's this? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Vicki. Look, Vicki, I need you to look up the booking card and rough arrest on a defendant named Beaumont. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all I have. I believe it's a surname but I'm not sure. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis enters the area, standing over Ordell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to wait in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go wait in the car. Wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell pulls out a heavy-duty keychain with a shitload of keys on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the keys, man. Listen to music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one is for the car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell finds it. While he goes through the keys, Vicki comes back on the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max speaks with her as he fills out his papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one's for the ignition... (holding a little black box)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but you gotta hit this thing to shut the alarm off and unlock the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't got to do nothing. Just point at it and push the button. You'll hear the car go "bleep." That means the alarm's off and the doors are open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now play the volume as loud as you want but don't touch my levels. I got them set just the way I want 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis walks out of the office. He goes up to Ordell's black Mercedes. He points the little black box at it. The car goes BLEEP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gingerly approaches it, opens the door and climbs inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On his prior, he served nine months, and he's working on four years' probation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what he's on probation for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will they consider this a violation of his probation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do consider this a violation of his probation. Your boy's looking at ten years, plus the concealed weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, he won't like that. Beaumont don't got a doin' time disposition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your name and address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell Robbie. O-R-D-E-L-L. R-O-B-B-I- E. 1436 Florence Boulevard. Compton 90222.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I need you to count your money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell hands him the Lakers bag. Max takes the money out putting it on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope you don't mind me askin' where you keepin' my money till I get it back. In your drawer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the street a Great Western. It goes in a trust account. You'll need to fill out an Application for Appearance Bond, an Indemnity Agreement, a Contingent Promissory Note. That's the one, if Beaumont skips and I go after him, you pay the expenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaumont ain't going nowhere. (he takes a pen out of his pocket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max pulls the forms from his desk, and lays them in front of Ordell. Max goes back to counting the money. Ordell reads the first agreement then says;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wondering. What if before the court date gets here, Beaumont gets hit by a bus or something and dies. (he puts the form down and looks at Max)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get my money back, don't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pressing a BLACK BUTTON next to the name, "BEAUMONT LIVINGSTON".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEAUMONT LIVINGSTON, wearing no shirt, sweatpants, and smoking a fatty answers the intercom, which buzzes loudly. We can hear JAY LENO interviewing a CELEBRITY on TV OFFSCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell stands outside the security gate of Beaumont's Hollywood apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSEUP - Ordell's lips talking into the intercom speaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your benefactor, nigga. Buzz me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSEUP - Beaumont's finger pressing the entry button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSEUP - The doorknob on the security gate, BUZZING. Ordell's hand comes into frame twisting it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaumont opens his apartment door, fatty between his fingers. He sees Ordell approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell greets him, arms spread out in hug mode, with a big smile across his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at you and your free ass. Come over and give me a motherfuckin' hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck can I say? I'm serious, man. What the fuck can I say? Thank you... thank you... thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was there for your ass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. Laughing his hustler's laugh and bumping Beaumont's fist hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see,ГЇit works like this. You get your ass in trouble, I get your ass out. That's my job. And I don't mind tellin ya, nigga, it's steady work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still scared as a motherfucker, Ordell. They talkin' like they serious 'bout me doin' that machine gun time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, man. They just tryin' to put a fright in your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's what they want to do, they're doin' it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old is that machine gun shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three years. That crime's old, man. They ain't got room in prison for all the motherfuckers out there killin' people. How they gonna find room for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what they're tellin' me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why they call it "fuckin' with ya." Now you wanna hear how we retaliate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaumont takes a hit off the fatty and nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow I pick you up, take you to Century City, meet my lawyer. Now let me tell you a little bit about my lawyer. His name is Stacin Goins and this nigga is a junkyard dog! He's my own private Johnie Cochran. In fact, he'd kick Johnie Cochran's ass. And like Johnie Cochran, dude hates fuckin' cops. I'm serious, this man lives to fuck with the police. So as a favor, I had him look at your case. Stacin told me you aint got shit to worry about. They just fuckin' wit ya. So we sic the junkyard dog on their ass, make 'em - (he bumps fist with Beaumont) ... Stop fuckin' wit ya!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, c'mon in, man. I was just - you know - smokin' a fatty, watchin' TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, man. I gotta be someplace. I was kinda hopin you could come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I hate to be the kinda nigga, does a nigga a favor - then BAM - hits a nigga up for a favor in return. But I'm afraid I gotta be that kinda nigga.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That requires me goin out tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaaaawww man, I wasn't plannin' on goin no place. It's twelve o'clock, man. I'm home, I'm high -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the fuck you at home? Cause I spent ten thousand dollars gittin' your ass home. (changes tone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I gotta problem. I need help, and you can help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaumont comes out of the apartment, sporting Nikes and a Queen Latifah t-shirt. He locks his front door and walks with Ordell to his car. They talk the whole way. We STEDICAM in front of them the whole way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it ain't so much a problem a a situation. Remember I sold those three M-60 machine guns outta the five I got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna sell the other two tonight. This group of Koreans in Koreatown have started a Neighborhood Watch kinda thing. And they want a few weapons so the neighborhood niggas know they mean business. So I'm gonna sell 'em my two machine guns tonight. Only problem, I aint never dealt with these Koreans before. Now I aint worried. Asians are by and large real dependable. They don't want no trouble. You might argue about price, but you aint gotta worry about them shootin' you in the back. But I got me kind of a rule. Never do business with nobody you ain't never done business with before without backup. That's why I need you, backup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I ain't ready to be goin' out nowhere -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Let me finish. Can I finish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trunk of a car is opened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell bends down into the trunk and pulls out a pump action shotgun. Beaumont obviously doesn't want any part of any Ordell game that requires a pump action shotgun as a playing piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're gonn be in the trunk holding onto the shotgun. And I'm going to tell them I'm opening up my trunk to show 'em my goods. I open up the trunk, you pop up, rack that bad boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck that shit, man. I ain't shootin' anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck I tell you. You don't hafta shoot nobody. Just hold the gun. They'll get the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't gittin' in that trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're only goin' to Koreatown. You'll be in there - ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-uh. I ain't riding in that trunk no minutes. Why don't I just ride with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't ride with me. The surprise effect is ninety percent of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry, man, but I ain't gittin' in that trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you do me this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't doin' you no way. I just ain't climbin' in that trunk. I got a problem with small places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, my ass has got a problem spending ten thousand dollars of my own goddam money to get ungrateful, peanut-head niggas outta jail, but I do it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, man, I know I owe you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Well, if you owe me, git your ass in the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - I wanna help you, but I don't wanna be locked in the trunk of no car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I wanted to spend ten thousand dollars on your ass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answer the question, nigga. Do you think I wanted to spend the thousand dollars on your ass? Yes or no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the only way to help you was to do that, so I did it. (pause) Okay, how 'bout this? After we're through fuckin' with these Koreans, I take you to Roscoe's Chicken and Waffles. My treat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just think, man. That Scoe's special, smothered in gravy and onions. Get a side of red beans and rice. Uuuuummmmm, that's some good eatin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaumont and Ordell laugh together... the Beaumont says;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now exactly how long I gotta be in this motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaumont in the trunk, holding the shotgun. The trunk lid is SLAMMED closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell walks around the car, climbs into the plush interior of the Olds and turns on the engine. It comes to life with a SOFT RUMBLE. He puts a tape in the player inside the dash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool, old-school R&B fills the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell cruises, moving his head to the rhythm and mouthing the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drives for awhile, just groovin' on the music...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell switches the engine and the music off. The cab goes black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans over the passenger seat, opening the glovebox. A tiny light turns on when the glovebox is opened. It's the only light in the cab. Ordell leaves it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In silence he takes one glove out and puts it on his right hand. Then with his gloved hand, reaches in the glovebox and pulls out a five-shot .38 snubby. He closes the glovebox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Olds is parked out in the middle of some urban nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell gets out, sticks the snubby in his pants, and walks to the back of the Olds. He sticks his key in the trunk and says;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trunk opens. Beaumont is hunched on his side with the shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wondering. Did any federal people come visit you in jail and I should be watching my ass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't tell me if they did and I wouldn't blame you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell takes the snubby out of his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaumont quick-racks the pump shotgun, pulls the trigger, and hears the click you hear from an empty weapon. He racks it again, CLICK then BAM. Beaumont is shot hard in the chest. He goes back into he trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell puts one more shot in his head, BAM, tosses the weapon on top of the dead body and closes the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell's Beaumont problem is solved. He climbs back into the cab, turns on the engine. We hear the old-school R&am song come back on, but VERY LOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis sits on a bed in a flophouse motel room, flipping from one channel to another with a remote control, drinking cocktails from a can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. He answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell is sitting parked in the comfy-cozy cab of the Olds, listening to soul music with his tiny cellular phone next to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin' really. Just kinda goin' back and forth. They had some black girl from some black show on Jay Leno. I watched that for a bit, but I kept flippin channels cause I didn't know who she was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you don't know. I said guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talkin' to you from the comfy- cozy interior of an Oldsmobile parked outside your nasty-ass welfare motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, man. I just told you, I'm comfortable. I ain't about to walk into that roach motel and get uncomfortable. You bring your ass out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then put your goddam drawers on, and get your ass out here. I got somethin' to show you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, having just thrown on some pants, walks outside his room and sees Ordell's big, black Oldsmobile parked in front of the motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he approaches, the power window on the driver's side comes down, revealing a comfortable Ordell sitting back in his seat looking up at Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what your problem is, Louis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis doesn't say anything, he just puts his hands in his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you're a good guy. When you go into a deal you don't go in prepared to take that motherfucker all the way. You go in looking for a way out. And it ain't cause you're scared neither. It's cause you think you're a good guy, and you think there's certain things a good guy won't do. That's where we're different, me and you. Cause me, once I decide I want something, aint a goddam motherfuckin' thing gonna stop me from gittin' it. I gotta use a gun get what I want, I'm gonna use a gun. Nigga gets in my way, nigga gonna get removed. Understand what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trunk opens showing Beaumont shot in the chest with half his head blown off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis looks inside, see Beaumont, looks at Ordell, then back to Beaumont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An employee I had to let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He put himself in a situation where he was gonna have to do ten years in the penetentiary, that's what he did. (taking out a Viceroy and lighting it up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you know Beaumont, you know there aint no way in hell he can do no ten years. And if you know that, you know Beaumont's gonna go any goddam thing Beaumont can to keep from doin' those ten years including telling the Federal government everything they want to know about my ass. Now that, my friend, is a clear case of him or me. And you best believe it aint gonna be me. You know what I'm sayin'? You gonna come in on this with me, you gotta be prepared to go all the way. I got me so far over a half-a-million dollars sittin' in lockboxes in a bank in Cabo San Lucas. Me and Mr. Walker make us one more delivery, I'm gonna have me over a million. You think I'm gonna let this little cheese eatin' nigga here fuck that up? Shit, you better think again. 'Fore I let this deal get fucked up, I'll shoot that nigga in the head, and ten niggas look just like em. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we on the same page then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell smiles (not his hustler smile, but a genuine smile).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of airplanes landing and taking off can be heard underneath this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We look down a row of cars in an enclosed parking garage at LAX. Jackie Brown, the Cabo Air stewardess from the opening credits, walks into frame. We dolly behind her as she walks down the row of cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young plainclothes cop, MARK DARGUS, walks up to her, holding open his I.D. case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Detective Mark Dargus. L.A.P.D. can I ask what you have in that bag?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual things. I'm a flight attendant with Cabo Air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young plainclothes cop RAY NICOLET, enters the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I be of some assistance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jackie pulls the cigarettes (Davidoffs) from her purse, she says to Ray;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Special Agent Ray Nicolet with Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms. Would you mind if we looked in that bag?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie lights her cigarette with a yellow Bic lighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would I mind? Do I have a choice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the right to say "no." And I have the right to make you wait here with Ray while I go get a warrant. And if I don't want to go through all that trouble, I could just take you in on suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All he wants to do is peek in your bag. I'll watch he doesn't take anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dargus lays the flight bag on the pavement, gets down on his haunches, and starts feeling through her things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A soiled blouse, uniform skirt, - then a manila envelope, a fat one, nine-by-twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie watches him straighten the clasp...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opens it. Out drops several packets of one hundred dollar bills secured with rubberbands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say there's about, oh, fifty thousand dollars here. What would you say Ray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That looks like fifty thousand dollars from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not saying anything at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I were to tell you "no it isn't..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should know if you bring in anything over ten thousand you have to declare it. You forgot or what? You could get a two hundred and fifty thousand dollar fine, plus two years in prison. Now you want to talk to us about it, or you want to talk to Customs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Jackie, Hope you don't mind if I call you Jackie. They're a bunch of fuckin' pricks in Customs. Something about that job makes them kinda hard to get along with. Now, do you want to talk with a bunch of suspicious, disagreeable people like them, or a couple good-hearted guys like Mark and myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting in a chair facing the two offscreen detectives. Jackie lights up a cigarette. We don't leave the CLOSEUP until noted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, this is my office. There's no smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could, smart ass... or we could work out what's known as a Substantial Assistance Agreement. That is if you're willing to cooperate. Tell us who gave you the money and who you're giving it to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie doesn't sat anything... she just smokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can she afford a good one is the question. Otherwise she'll be in Sybill Brand three weeks easy before the Public Defender gets around to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever heard of a fella named Beaumont Livingston?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know Beaumont? That's funny 'cause Beaumont knows you. Well he did know you, Beaumont was found in the trunk of a car - dead. Shot twice. Once in the head and once in the chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had the chance to talk to Beaumont yesterday. You see, like you, Beaumont found himself in some hot water. He was looking at ten years he was pretty sure he didn't want to do and was understandably concerned. Now maybe you don't know Beaumont, but Beaumont knew you, and maybe so does the guy who blew Beaumont's head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't want to talk to us, I guess we'll just have to hand you over to Customs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cut to the detective and the special agent for the first time in the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Miss Brown, there's basically three types of people that we come along in the performance of our duty. One is, INNOCENT PEOPLE. Victims, witnesses, innocent bystanders... You ain't any of these. Then there's two; CRIMINALS. These sonabitches have dedicated their lives to a life outside the law. That ain't you either. Where you belong is the third category. The category we refer to as LOSERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie's eyes don't even narrow at the insult. She just says without expression;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're both? In 1985 you were flying for TWA and got busted for carrying drugs. You were carrying them for a pilot husband of yours. He did time and you got off. But that ended your career with the big airlines. Cut to thirteen years later. You're forty-four years of age. You're flying for the shittiest little shuttle-fucking piece of shit Mexican airline that there is. Where you make a whopping twelve-thousand dollars a year. That ain't a hulluva lot to show for a twenty year career. And to top it off, you're going to jail. Now true, the judge, even with your prior, will probably only give you a year or two. But this doesn't seem like the time of life you got years to throw away. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, we don't like trying losers like they're criminals. But in the absence of a criminal, we will try you. Now, wasn't this money given to you by an American living in Mexico by the name of Cedric Walker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie remains unmoved by this monologue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, ol' Beaumont wasn't much for talkin', either. Yeah, he told us about you and Mr. Walker, but whoever the hell it was he worked for out here, he wouldn't say. Could it be the same person you were supposed to deliver this money to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie just stares at them, saying nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dargus sits behind his desk, with Jackie's flight bag on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like your permission to open this again. So we'll know exactly how much money we're talkin' about here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie gets up from her chair, walks over to the desk, unzips the bag, takes out the manila envelope and drops it on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While you're at it, let me see what else is in there. You mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches in the bag and brings out a pocketbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dargus points at a clear plastic bag with pills and packets in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicolet takes out the bills from the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see what else is in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicolet takes the bills and looks inside the envelope. His expression changes to a shit-eating grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicolet pulls out a clear cellophane sandwich bag with a half-inch or so of white powder inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what would this be, Sweet and Low?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is that shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what it looks like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You planted that shit on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicolet and Dargus laugh at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't enough for Trafficking, but how 'bout Posession with the Intent to Distribute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I wouldn't be so sure. What with all the cash, I think I could go with Conspiracy to Traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tellin' you, I don't know nothin' about that fuckin' shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, Miss Brown. Why don't you have a seat and tell us who might know something about this fuckin' shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie just looks at the two grinning Cheshire cats as the balance of power rolls over on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Los Angeles County Jail bus pulls up behind the Torrance Court House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, now wearing County Jail blues, sits next to another BLACK WOMAN. Their hands cuffed together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus stops. A rough-looking FEMALE COUNTY SHERIFF unlocks the gate that encloses the prisoners. Then explains in a you-better-do-exactly-what-I-say manner, how they're going to leave the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MANY WOMEN, including Jackie, all wearing county blues and handcuffed to each other, exit the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SHERIFFS lead them into the back entrance to the court house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dargus and Nicolet confer with the PUBLIC DEFENDER, an attractive blonde woman in a nice business suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she'll cooperate with us, we'll turn possession with intent into plain ol' Possession, and she can bond outta here for one thousand bucks. If she doesn't help us, we'll go for the Intent and request a twenty-five-thousand dollar bond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and the Public Defender. Jackie, in her county blues; Public Defender in her nice suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell those guys they'll have to do one helluva lot better than that before I'll even say 'hi' to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's the State's offer. If you plead to possession and tell L.A.P.D. what they want to know, your bond will be set at one-thousand dollars. If you don't, L.A.P.D. will request one at twenty- five thousand based on your prior record and risk of flight. If you don't post it or don't know anyone who can, you'll spend six to eight weeks in County before your arraignment comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And cooperate? You might get probation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the prior? You could get anywhere from a year to five depending on the judge. You want to think about it? You got two minutes before we're up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a full schedule in court today. Jackie sits with a bunch of other females wearing county blues in the defendant's area (where the jury sits during a jury trial)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dargus and Nicolet sit in the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JUDGE reads the next case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie rises amongst the other defendants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The charge is possession of Narcotics with the Intent to Distribute. How does your client plead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wishes to stand mute, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Detective Dargus - You're the arresting officer in his case, correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a recommendation for bail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do, your honor. Based on the defendant's prior conviction and the extreme possibility of flight due to her occupation, the State requests a bond of no less than twenty-five thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge looks at the report, then at Jackie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll set bond at ten thousand and set the date of August 14th for the arraignment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's six weeks from now, Miss Brown. We'll continue this matter then. Owens, case 72242.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dargus sits down next to Nicolet. They smile and giggle together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie sees them giggle like fifth graders. It fucking pisses her off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go from a CLOSEUP of a boiling Jackie, to a perspective from the back of the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Jackie in the defendant's area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the two happy detectives walk past us on their way out of the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sits in the back, watching the proceedings without any expression. When he's seen enough, he stands up and out of the shot leaving an EMPTY FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bathroom door in Max's office. We hear a toilet flush behind it. The door opens, and Max Cherry emerges, zipping up his pants with a TV guide in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up and stops dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell sitting oh-so comfortably in the chair in front of Max's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unh... unh... unh... I din't hear you wash your hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max looks at Ordell, then takes his place behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door was opened, so I just came right in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got some more business for ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? What did he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is an airline stewardess. Got caught coming back from Mexico with some blow. They set her bond this afternoon at ten thousand. Now, what I was thinkin', you could use the ten thousand you owe me from Beaumont and move it over on to the stewardess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bond for possession is only a thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fuckin' wit' her. They callin' it Possession with Intent. A black woman in her forties gets busted with less than two ounces on her, they call that shit Intent. Same shit happened to a movie star. It's Possession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had, I believe it was... fifty grand on her, too. There was a cop at the hearing. Young guy with L.A.P.D. wanted her bond set at twenty-five thousand, saying there was a risk of flight. Jackie being a stewardess and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before we start talking about stewardess, let's get Beaumont out of the way first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting back in the chair - almost grinning - but not quite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody with a grudge blew Beaumont's brains out - hey, that rhymes - blew Beaumont's brains out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very first motherfuckin' thing they did. They see I put up a big money bond on my boy, they start thinking with that where-there's-smoke-there's fire logic. They roust my ass outta bed, ten o'clock in the morning. Fuckin' scare my woman, Sherona, half to death. She thought they were gonna take my ass away for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stewardess. Do you know her last name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does she do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who says she does anything for me? She's my friend. When my friends get into trouble, I like to help 'em out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what the police thought. I told them I'm unemployed, how could I have anybody work for me? Now I bail out Jackie, I'm liable to have the police on me again, huh? Wanting to know was she doing things for me, was she bringing me that money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this, me and you, like a lawyer- client relationship? The lawyer can't tell nothing he hears?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not my client until you get busted and I bond you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's no - what do you call it - confidentiality between us? Why would I tell you anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause you want me to know what a slick guy you are. You got stewardesses bringing you fifty grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would a stewardess bring me fifty grand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to speculate on what you do. I'd say you're in the drug business, except the money's moving in the wrong direction. Whatever you're into, you seem to be getting away with it, so more power to you. Okay you want another bond, and you want to move over the ten thousand you put down on Beaumont to the stewardess. That means paperwork. I have to get a death certificate, present it to the court, fill out a receipt for return of bond collateral, then type up another application. An indemnity agreement -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Jackie aint got time for all that shit -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - I'm telling you what I have to do. What you have to do, in case you forgot, is come up with premium of a thousand bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it. I just don't got it on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, come back when you do, and I'll bond out the stewardess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you know I'm good for it. Thousand bucks ain't shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I don't see it in front of me, you're right. It ain't shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you need to look at this with a little compassion. Jackie ain't no criminal. She ain't used to this kinda treatment. I mean, gangsters don't give a fuck - but for the average citizen, coupla nights in County fuck with your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell, this isn't a bar, an you don't have a tab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just listen for a second. We got a forty-year-old, gainfully employed black woman, falsely accused -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falsely accused? She didn't come back from Mexico with cocaine on her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falsely accused of Intent. If she had that shit - and mind you, I said "if" - it was just her shit to get high with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is white guilt supposed to make me forget I'm running a business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell gives up and takes an envelope out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, man. I got your money. But don't you ever ask me for no fuckin' favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's early evening; and Max's powder-blue Seville is driving to the County Jail with a client, a young Hispanic woman of twenty named ANITA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow I'll talk to your probation officer. Karen's a good kid, but she's mad at you, because you lied to her. This business about your grandmother's funeral

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went. I did. I took my mother and little brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you didn't ask permission. You broke a trust. If you had asked, Karen probably would have let you. I'm sure she would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. That's why I went.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then you told her you were home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, 'cause I didn't ask her if I could go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe it's a language problem. (getting stern)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita, you ever cause this much heartache over something that could easily be avoided, I'll never write you again. You understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it. I don't care how many times your mother calls or how much she cries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max and Anita, side by side. Anita's hands are cuffed behind her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dropping off and picking up. Dropping of Lopez, Anita. Picking up Brown, Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're at the admitting desk of the L.A. County Jail. Max undoes Anita's handcuffs, while a SHERIFF waits to take her away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're gonna call Karen tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses Max on the cheek and the Sheriff takes her away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max puts the cuffs away, sits on a bench, takes out a Len Deighton paperback and begins to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still reading his novel. We hear offscreen, a SHERIFF'S voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max puts his book down and see -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie being led into the Admitting Area by TWO SHERIFFS. She's wearing her stewardess uniform and carrying a small envelope with her belongings in it and her shoes. When Max was imagining a woman in her forties, he had someone with a bit of wear and tear on them in mind. But this Jackie Brown's a knockout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he watches her, she steps out of the County Jail slippers she was wearing and slips into her shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He approaches, handing her his card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Brown... I'm Max Cherry. I'm your bail bondsman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the card and shakes his hand saying nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can give you a lift home if you'd like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max puts his key in the ignition, when Jackie asks;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you really a bail bondsman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave you my card there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max digs the case out of his pocket, hands it to her, then reaches up and turns on the light above them for her to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who put up my bond? Ordell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max rolls down his window at the front gate. A DEPUTY comes out of the gatehouse and hands through the window Max's .38 revolver, cylinder opened. Max hands the Deputy his pass in exchange for the gun, says "thanks", then puts the .38 in his glovebox in front of Jackie. He drives on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, ever been to the Riverbottom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. It's a cop hangout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't we just stop at a seven- eleven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you might want a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love one, but not there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could stop at the Hilton by the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's kind of a sports bar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does it need to be dark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I look like I just got outta jail, that's why. You droppin' me off at home, right? There's a place by me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big neon sign of a cockatoo sits on op of a red brick inn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP - A KNOB is pulled out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie picks up a pack of Mild Seven's cigarettes from the bottom of a cigarette machine. She crosses the bar to join Max, sitting at a small table waiting for her to return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cockatoo Inn is just what Jackie was looking for. A dark and red cocktail lounge in Hawthorne off of Hawthorne Boulevard by the apartment where the stewardess lives (about ten minutes from LAX)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clientele of the Cockatoo is an older, black crowd and an even older white crowd who'd been coming here years before it became a black bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A JUKEBOX plays soft, old-school R&B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and Max sit side by side at a small table, lit by a bar candle in a red glass thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max drinks Bushmills over crushed ice. Jackie drinks white wine. Jackie opens her Mild Sevens, offering one to Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks, I quit three years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten pounds. I lose it and put it back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I don't quit. If I can't fly anymore, I'm gonna have a bitch of a time gettin' my brand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davidoffs. I get 'em in Mexico. They're hard to find here. I was locked up with the last two getting legal advice from a woman who was in for bustin' her boyfriend's head open with a baseball bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was more helpful than the fuckin' Public Defender. (she takes a sip of wine)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know - I guess what I need is a lawyer, find out what my options are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I figured out the other day I've written something like' fifteen thousand bonds since I've been in the business. I'd say about eighty percent of them were at least drug related. If you want, I can help you look at your options.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie takes the talk in a different direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, as a matter of fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment of silence between them, they both take drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So far I've been told I can cooperate and get probation, maybe. Or, I can stand mute and get as much as five years. Does that sound right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say if you're tried and found guilty you won't get more than a year and a day. That's State time. Prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they won't want to take you to trial. They'll offer you simple Possession, a few months of County time, and a year or two probation. (pointing to her drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max gestures to an older black cocktail waitress named ROWEN for two more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who put the dope in your bag?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but that's not what this was about. They were fuckin waitin' for my ass. They knew I had that money, they even knew the amount. The one who searched my bag, from L.A.P.D., Dargus, hardly even looked at it. "Oh, I'd say there's fifty thousand here. What would you say?" But all they could do was threaten me and hand me over to Customs, and I could tell they didn't want to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wanted you to tell them what you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had 'em too. I burnt those two Starky and Hutch motherfuckers down. Then their asses lucked out and found that coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did they want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who gave me the money and who I was giving it to. And some guy they found in a trunk with his head blown off. Said it was him who told them 'bout me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Waitress comes with the drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get you two some popcorn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him. How do you know 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wrote him on Monday. They found him dead on Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The federal agent kinda half hinted Ordell might of done Beaumont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mentioned a guy from L.A.P.D., but you didn't mention the Federal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray Nicolet with Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the one who wants you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the other guy who busted me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause if he busted you, you'd play hell bonding out of federal court. He doesn't want you mad at him, he wants you to tell him what you know. He uses you to get a line on Ordell, make a case, then take him federal. You know what Ordell's into?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a pretty good idea. Ordell aint no bootlegger and I doubt he's smugglin' Cuban cigars. So that only leaves one thing an A.T.F. man would be interested in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie waits a moment before answering, weighs things in her mind and makes a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to bring over ten thousand at a time. That's the legal limit, so I never brought more than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many trips did you make?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all in lock boxes in a Mexico bank. But he's got a problem. He's - what do you call it when you got money, but don't have cash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. He's cash poor. He kept on me till I finally said okay. I'll bring whatever fits in a nine-by- twelve envelope. I got paid five hundred dollars, and his friend, Mr. Walker, in Mexico gave me the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you knew bringing anything over ten thousand was against the law, why not pack a hundred grand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever it was had to fit in my bag and not hit you in the face if the bag was opened. This ain't solvin' my problem. I gotta figure out a way to either keep my job or get out of trouble. I'm of today, but if I can't leave the country I'm out of a job. And if I don't got a job, I can't hire a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask A.T.F. They might give you permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Jackie, you got caught, you're gonna have to give 'em something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if all I can give 'em is Ordell's name - I don't really know shit about what he does or how he does it - That don't give me much to bargain with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give 'em what you got. Offer to help. Show a willingness to be helpful. You want to stay out of jail, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max looks at Jackie thinking about something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think maybe I have more options than I thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting in his black Mercedes, parked across the street from Jackie's apartment building in Hawthorne. Johnny Cash is playing inside his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the windshield, he sees Max's powder-blue Cadillac Seville pull up to Jackie's apartment. She gets out, ten bends down and talks to him through the window of the passenger side door. Then makes a goobye gesture and turns, walking into her apartment complex. Max drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Johnny Cash continues crooning, Ordell puts on his gloves. Then opens up his glovebox, taking out a little Targa .22 pistol. He steps out of the car, slipping the pistol into his coat pocket. We STEDICAM in front of him as he walks across the street to Jackie's apartment. Once inside the complex, Ordell passes us and WE FOLLOW BEHIND HIM, up to Jackie's ground-floor apartment door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives it a soft knock with one knuckle. He waits a moment, then Jackie opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was expecting you. Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie holds the door open for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell steps inside. He moves over by a halogen lamp in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie still standing by the door. She doesn't look frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got some vodka in the freezer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell turns the halogen lamp to dim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, why don't you be a good hostess and make me a screwdriver?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie moves into the kitchen area. Ordell follows her, hanging in the doorway, while she makes the drink. Jackie doesn't turn on the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking a glass from the cupboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who you think got your ass outta jail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opening the freezer and filling a glass with ice cubes and taking out vodka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same guy who put me in, thanks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you get caught with blow, that's our business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opens refrigerator, light cuts into the kitchen. She takes out orange juice, then closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell has to stop and think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. I bet it was that present Mr. Walker was sending Melanie. Yaaaah, he's the one musta put it in there if you didn't. Oh, man, that shit's uncalled for, baby, and I apologize. I 'magine they asked you a shitload of questions about it, huh? All that money, want to know where you got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie doesn't answer. She just walks up to Ordell handing him his yellow drink in the darkness. Ordell takes it, continues to look at Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'magine they asked who you givin' it to, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I wanted to talk to a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You positive about that? You weren't nervous and let something slip by mistake? If you did, I ain't mad, I just gotta know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not asking the right questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she walks past him back to the living room. She goes over to the halogen lamp, turning the light up brighter, then moves by the door, still standing and looking at Ordell in the kitchen doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they asked if I knew Mr. Walker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell by the halogen lamp. He turns it back to dim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell directly in front of Jackie, he gently places his gloved hands on her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's mighty honorable of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell's gloved fingertips move up her collarbone to her throat, gently touching her skin. Jackie locks eyes with his, but still shows no fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This fella Beaumont, they say what happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment the film becomes a:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the RIGHT-HAND SIDE is Ordell with his hands barely touching Jackie's throat. On the LEFT-HAND SIDE is Max driving home in his Seville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max drives home, an almost moony romantic look no his face. He can't stop thinking about Jackie. During the night she'd have a gleam in her eyes, the look saying; "WE COULD HAVE FUN". Unless she was appraising kinda him with the look, making a judgment and what it said was; "I COULD USE YOU". Either way it was a turn-on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max pulls into the driveway of his small house in Torrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, somebody musta been real mad at Beaumont. Or  they were afraid of what he might say to keep from doin some time. I'magine from time-to-time they asked you a whole shitload of questions. And you didn't give 'em no answer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie shakes her head from side to side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell moves his thumbs from her collarbone to the middle of her throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie shakes her head from side to side without her eyes leaving his. Reaches over the seat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a reason to be nervous with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With his hands on Jackie's throat, staring into the woman's eyes, from BELOW FRAME then feels something hard the fuck against his crotch. Neither break eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max takes his keys, then to the glove box...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what I think it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's a gun pressing against my dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought right... Now take your hands from around my throat, nigga.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell flashes his hustler's smile and lets go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie turns Ordell around, gun firmly in his back, and pushes him against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut your ass up and grab the wall!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie has Ordell against the wall and is frisking him the way a cop would. She finds the .22 pistol in his pocket

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, baby, that's got nothin' to do with you. I just carry that. You been listenin' to them cops too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops didn't try and strangle my ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, Jackie, I was just playin' with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I ain't playin with you. I'm gonna unload both these motherfuckers, you don't do what I tell you. Understand what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shoves both guns in Ordell's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, you understand what I'm saying

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go sit over in that chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell moves over to a chair across from the couch. Ordell still tries bullshit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tellin' you, those cops been fuckin' wit your mind. They turn black against black, that's how they do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut your raggedy ass up and sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put both hands behind our head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie turns the halogen lamp to light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta tell you to shut up one more time, I'm gonna shut you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie sits down on the couch, holding a gun in each hand, both pointed dead at Ordell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A coffee table lays between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell, hands behind his head, continues to mumble...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just came here to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Way I see it, me and you only got one thing to talk about. What you willing to do for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell looks at her a moment and says;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can get you a good lawyer -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get realistic, baby. Sooner or later they're gonna get around to offering me a plea deal, and you know that. That's why you came here to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - It's okay. I forgive you. Now, let's say if I tell on you, I walk. And if I don't, I go to jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred thousand put in an escrow account in my name, if I'm convicted up to a year, or put on probation. If I have to do more than a year, you pay another hundred thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell just takes in what the woman said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell has to smile at the woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been thinkin about that, too, and I got me a idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell goes through FRAME, out the door, Jackie steps into FRAME, and talks with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to the cops tomorrow and tell you if it's on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie shuts the door, and leaves FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a knock-knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except it's day. Jackie in a bathrobe steps into FRAME and opens the door. She says to the yet-unseen-by-camera visitor;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want your gun, don't you? Come in. I'll go get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves FRAME, and Max enters it, closing the door behind him. Max stands by the door, a little surprised and a touch pissed at the nonchalantness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
