dialogues.text: As he stands on the threshold to her living room, waiting for her to return with the gun, feeling foolish, he thinks about hauling her ass back to the stockade. That'll change her expression, he'd bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She returns from the bedroom, gun in hand, wearing a sort of sad smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, I'm sorry. I was afraid if I asked to borrow it you'd say no. You'd have to. Would you like some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, as quickly as the anger rose in Max, it dissipates completely, leaving only curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie head to the kitchen, making the coffee. Max sits at the dining table off of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get a chance to use it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I felt a lot safer having it. My milk went bad when I was in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts a finger in the coffeemaker and starts scooping coffee in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to hang on to it awhile? It wouldn't be legal, but if it makes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie goes to the sink, filling the coffee pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, but I have my own now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You went out this morning and bought a gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You went out this morning and bought a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pouring water into the coffee machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just say I got one, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max's eyes follow her to the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie ends her knees and goes through a stack of records leaned up against the wall on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't wait till I got home last night and wash my hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finds a record, takes it out of the pile, removes the album from the sleeve, and places it on her stereo turntable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never got into the whole CD revolution?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a few. But I can't afford to start all over again. I got too much time and money invested in my records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song starts; it's an old romantic soul music number from the early seventies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you can't get new stuff on records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie picks up her cigarettes off the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't buy new stuff that often.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie enters the kitchen door frame by Max. She lights a cigarette and stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max listens to the soul song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called in sick this morning. As far as the airline knows, I'm still available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know yet. 'm going to talk with Dargus and Nicolet today. Do what you suggested. Offer to help and see what happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I meant was have a lawyer do the negotiating for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk to them first. I know more now about Ordell's money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if the A.T.F. guy is the one who wants you, that'll only interest him up to a point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lot of money. About a half-a- million dollars. All of it in Cabo in safe deposit boxes and more comin in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie goes back in the kitchen. Coffee's almost there, but not quite. She pulls down two mugs from a cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had his doubts at first. But he's always trusted me an wants more than anything to believe he still can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs me. Without me all that money is just gonna sit over there in Cabo. Sugar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. There's gotta be other ways to get it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, but 'm the only one he's ever used. He can't trust his other people. They're crooks. He can try bringing I in himself, but Ordell sure don't want to go through no Customs line. Either he recruits another Cabo stewardess, or he continues to trust me. I made him feel he still can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie walks to the table with the two coffee mugs and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you get it out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same way I been don', but first they got to let me go back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna offer to set him up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I get let off. Otherwise, fuck 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very possible Ordell's killed somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't goin' to jail, and I ain't doin' that probation thing again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie takes a drink of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel about getting old?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not old. You look great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm asking how you feel. Does it bother you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not really something I think about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm a little sensitive about my hair. It started falling out ten years ago. So I did something about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine with it, or I wouldn't of done it, I did it to feel better about myself, and I do. When I look in the mirror it looks like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I can't really feel too sorry for you in that department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact, I'd make a bet that except possibly for an Afro - you look exactly the same as you did at twenty nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just feel like I'm always starting over. You said how many bonds you wrote?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've flown seven million miles. And I've been waitin' on people almost twenty years. The best job I could get after my bust was Cabo Air, which is about the worst job you can get in this industry. I make about sixteen thousand, with retirement benefits , ain't worth a damn. And now with this arrest hanging over my head, I'm scared. If I lose my job I gotta start all over again, but I got nothin to start over with. I'll be stuck with whatever I can get. And that scares me more than Ordell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.T.F. man, Ray Nicolet, moves down the hallway of the big building... ten heads for the office of Mark Dargus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches the closed door... raps on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicolet opens the door, revealing Dargus and Jackie Brown sitting in the office talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dargus stands up and says to Jackie;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me have a word outside with Agent Nicolet for a moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two detectives step outside and close the door on Jackie as she pulls out her cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants to make a deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants to go back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she willing to give us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hasn't one into specifics yet, she's been waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ain't said it, but she's not stupid, she knows it's you who wants her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside Dargus' office, smoking a Mild Seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dargus and Nicolet come back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for waiting, Jackie. Now tell me, what can we do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need permission to leave the country so I keep my job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need it tomorrow. If I don't show up for work tomorrow, I'm fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm working, I can help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, so now you know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never asked me if I did or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now you're telling us now you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course I do - I deliver money for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit. You know how he makes hi money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever see him sell guns?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how do you know he sells guns?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told me. Besides, why else would an A.T.F. man be after him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Short of wearing a wire, I'll do everything I can to help you throw his ass in jail. And in exchange for my help, I need permission to leave the country and immunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want much, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you do it or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two cops look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helmut Berger slaps a woman in the face with a newspaper, proclaiming he's the "mad dog." The film is an Italian Policier from the seventies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie sits in a comfy chair long-ways, bare legs hanging over the arm. As she watches the TV, she picks up a big bong with it's own handle. He takes a hit. Melanie's dressed in her usual Melanie-uniform of shorts and a loose top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door opens, and Ordell and Louis walk through it carrying shopping bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We notice that Louis is sportin' new duds. Louis' new "look" is a retro seventies-style bowling shirt and black jeans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, hey. I think somebody's got some new clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We been shoppin'. Can't have my boy running around lookin' like a bum on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't look like a bum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you did have a Salvation Army- thing going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell notices the bong in her hand and the smoke in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddam, girl. You gettin' high already. It's only two o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis sits on the couch. He smiles at the comeback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha-ha-ha. I'm serious, you smoke too much of that shit. That shit robs you of your ambition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if your ambition is to get high and watch TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two a coupla Cheech and Chongs, ain't ya. (he moves towards the phone - to Melanie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's okay, I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jackie... (throwing a hard look at Melanie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Jackie, I didn't get your message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell gives her a "silence" gesture and look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie trades a look with Louis like "I'm in trouble," all the while smiling like a shark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie holds up the bong, offering him a hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not on the phone, let's meet somewhere. But you gotta make sure they ain't followin' you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis has the bong in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie stays in her chair long-ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie sits at the bar talking on their phone. We see both sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's right on Hawthorne Boulevard and Manhattan Beach Boulevard. It's red brick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wait, you mean that place that has the big sign with a rooster on it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis exhales his smoke, does an older man cough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm just gettin' old. I can't smoke or laugh now it seems without coughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coughing opens up the capillaries. When you cough, you're getting air - in this case smoke - to parts of the lung that don't normally get used. Coughing's good - gets ya higher. My dad coughs when he smokes all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Louis, I have to go out awhile. So since you like gettin' high so much, why don't you stay here with Melanie, get high, and watch cartoons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell takes the remote control and turns the station till he finds a channel with cartoons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you just watch this for the next three hours, and I'll be back. Then, when I'm through with all my business, I'll get high. I get high at night. Walk me to the door, space girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie climbs out of the chair and walks Ordell to the door,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell says to her in the doorway;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope you don't mind keeping him company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try not to rip his clothes off 'em they're new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie gives him a sarcastic, "Oh, you're so funny" look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell kisses her quick on the mouth, then says past her;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back in an hour, man. Just hang with Mel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell leaves and Melanie closes the door. She turns around and looks at Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like this major meal in a shake you drink instead of having a big meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's what body builders drink to beef up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes into the kitchen and starts making her Metrix shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around and spots something interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a clear, plastic frame. Melanie, circa 1976, at about sixteen wearing roller-disco skates. Melanie, in a green setting, about five years ago, wearing a pretty Oriental- style dress, with a "smile for the camera" look on her face. The photo was obviously a picture of Melanie with somebody else that's been cut in half. Somebody's disembodied arm still rests on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis picks up the photo frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks and sees what he's talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was pretty much the same height now as I was then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noooo, I was a surfer girl. Besides, I was only fourteen. I couldn't go to discos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beach. Or get high, drop acid at a friend's place. I was a K.L.O.S. girl. I hated disco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hits Whip on her blender. It makes an infernal noise till she hits Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying the blender full of Metrix, she walks over and looks at the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was taken at a place called "Flippers." It was in Hollywood. Were you in L.A. back then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had done time together already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever go I one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to a few just to meet women. But I don't like to dance, and it's so fuckin; loud. During that whole scene I just drank in bars. (he points to the cut picture)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a picture of me in Japan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lived there for about nine months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the guy I lived with... his name was... Hir.Hirosh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must of made quite an impression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never got to know him, really. I couldn't speak Japanese, and his English was terrible. But I couldn't say anything, because his English was better than my Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. We didn't have much to say to each other anyway. I never got to know him that well, but I knew enough to know I wasn't missing much. I keep that, because of all the fuckin' time I was there, that's the only picture I got of me in Japan. (she points beyond her shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lies on the couch on his back and Melanie sits on top of him. They're going at it like a couple of fuck monkeys. Almost on the fade up, Louis cums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hops off and OUT OF FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that really hit the spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's over, let's get to know each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP a rack of CDs all beginning with "D" are flipped through, till it stops on one CD, "The Best of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max is standing in he soul music section o a music store. He lifts out the CD and turns it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has the song Jackie played this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles and takes the CD up to the register.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP the COCKATOO INN neon sign, unlit during the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell walks into the dark red cocktail lounge in the middle of the day and sees Jackie sitting at the bar drinking a white wine. Old-school soul plays on the jukebox. He sits next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta remember this place. This is all right. Two minutes from your crib, ten minutes from your work. Not bad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black bartender named FLOYD approaches Ordell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you come here on a Saturday night, you need nigga repellent keep 'em off your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a fine lookin' woman, Jackie. I bet you do a damn sight better than okay. You think anybody followed you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so, but it don't really matter. They know I'm meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the fuck they know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Floyd comes back with Ordell's screwdriver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell digs in his pocket and gives Floyd a five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told em? You told em it's me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, shit. That don't mean you gotta confirm it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, the only way I can get permission to fly is if I agree to help them. Which is what I have to appear to be doing. So I give them something they already know. You.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told them you got a half a million dollars in Mexico, and you want me to bring it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck's that got to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They know I'm delivering for you. I mention the half-million - they don't give a fuck about that - They want you with guns. So I say, well, if you want proof he's getting paid for selling them, let me bring the money in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP - Louis taking a hit off Melanie's bong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis and Melanie are back in the living room, kicking back, taking bong hits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Louis gets his hit, Melanie talks;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... so first he tries to get into the cocaine business but realizes right away that shit's too competitive. Piss the wrong person off, you get shot. So he says, fuck that - moves over to guns. You can sell guns wherever there's a demand. No one gives a shit. He acts like he's this big international arms dealer, when, come on, the only people he ever sold to were dopers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis finishes his hit and slides the bong back across the coffee table to Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems to be making out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, so far he is. But you have to admit he's not too bright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't go so far as to say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves his lips when he reads, what does that tell ya. Let's say he's streetwise. I'll give 'im that. He's still a fuck-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a major bong hit... holds in the smoke... then while holding in the smoke, says;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He killed a man worked for him the other night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you trying to tell me? I should get out of here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie lets out her stream of smoke and flashes her shark smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I'm saying at all. (pause) You know where he went?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went to meet that stewardess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie lets out a sarcastic laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live here. He drops in and out. He tell you about that half-million dollars he's got in Mexico?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course he did, he tells everybody who'll listen. That's what he's doin' with this stewardess. He's scheming how he can get it over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him and that stewardess get that money over here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and just take it from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie explaining the plan to Ordell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I make two deliveries. The first one with ten thousand, like a dry run. They watch it. See how it works. Then we do a second delivery, when I bring in the half mill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, naw, that's too much exposure. I ain't goin anywhere near that money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to. I told 'em you're real careful. You never pick up money yourself. You always send someone, and I never know who it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you just listen, you'll see it's a damn good idea. The first time I do it they're lurking about. They see me hand the ten thousand to someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. One of your friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next trip, when I come with all the money, it'll look like I hand it to the same one I did before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I give it to someone else first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they follow the wrong one thinkin' she's bringing it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we need two people, two women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the woman covered. Where you thinkin' about doin' this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinkin' the Del Amo Mall. In the food court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you see a piece of this for yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's my plan. We're in this together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it's my money, and I don't need me a partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't your partner, I'm your manager. I'm managing to get your money out of Mexico, into America, in your hands, and I'm managing to do all this under the nose of the cops. That makes me your manager, and managers get fifteen percent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's an agent. Manager's get fifteen percent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plus the same deal as before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's now getting late at night. Jackie comes home. She's dressed differently than she was at the Cockatoo. In fact, she looks like she's coming home from a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks into her bedroom... kicks off her shoes... takes her earring off, putting them on the night-stand by the bed... she sees that her answering machine is flashing. She hits play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We begin a SLOW ZOOM into the answering machine. Never seeing Jackie again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have on message. Sent at 8:06 P.M.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max's voice comes out of the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Jackie. It's Max. I was just calling to find out how everything went today with A.T.F. If you want to call me, my home number is 555-6788, or you can reach me at my office, which is 555-B-A-I-L. That's also on the card I gave you when we first met - I don't know if you still have that - but it's on it - Oh, let me give you my beeper number. It's 555-7839. Okay, so I'll talk to you later. Hope everything's well. Bye-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We se the huge Del Amo Mall from the parking area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Del Amo Mall on a lazy midday in the middle of the week. A few people, mostly black, mill around, but it's not like it is on the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The international food court, where fast-food versions of international cuisine are available to all the hungry Del Amo Mall shoppers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and Ordell sit at a table in the food court. She drinks an iced tea from Teriyaki Donut. A collection of Broadway shopping bags sit on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The money's in a Broadway shopping bag. I get some food, and sit down here in the food court. Then your girl comes - you got somebody yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's my ass facin' the penitentiary. You send some hard- headed roc whore, and she fucks things up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't gonna send no roc whore. The woman's cool, I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're outside the Del Amo UA Cinemas, a six-screen theater that's been in the Del Amo Mall since the early seventies. A small afternoon crowd is exiting the cinema, having just watched their matinee. Max Cherry is among them. He exits the theater, and strolls through the mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie moves a Broadway bag towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow with Ordell out of the food court, when he stops...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... He see Max Cherry strolling through the mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell almost steps into a store to get out of view. "What the fuck is Max Cherry doing here?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ordell watches, he sees Max head towards the food court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: walks into the food court. He stands looking a all the international fast food choices in front of him. As he tries to decide, he hears from behind him;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max turns and sees Jackie siting there drinking her iced tea, smoking her Mild Seven, and smiling up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, ignoring me. What're you up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty good. Me and Annette Bening are goin steady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, are you? Does she know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I don't believe she's ever heard of me. But that doesn't mean we're not going steady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching Max sit down and make himself comfortable at Jackie's table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think falling in live with movie stars is something that happens to a man as he gets older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it happen to all men?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd never be so bold as to speak for all men, but as or myself and a few of my friends, that's definitely the case. There's a lot of actresses out there you like, and there's some you have crushes on. But there's always one who you love. And with her it's sorta like going steady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For now. These relationships never last too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a smile on her face;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a goddam man for ya. Can't even be faithful to a fuckin' movie star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was your girl before Annette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, she's the girl who drove the bus in "Speed." She's cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's adorable. But I had to end it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm old enough to be her father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gesturing to the Broadway bags on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go back to work tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They seem to like the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring the money in and they follow it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yea, but I'm going to dress it up. Put the money in a shopping bag and hand it to someone I meet here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't actually do it that way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He always just picked it up at my place. But with A.T.F. involved, I want to stage it. You know, make it look more intriguing, like we know what the fuck we're doin'. Then it's up to Ray Nicolet, the A.T. F. guy to follow the shopping bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make the delivery somewhere in the mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right around here, in the food court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, leave the bag under the table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm helping him bring his money into America. He loves the idea. You just missed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we were goin' over everything. That's why all the bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I got your message. Ray wanted to have dinner. He wanted to talk about the sting we're plotting. That's what he calls it. A sting. He's being real nice to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think he's got a thing for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. But I'm thinking it might be something like he wants the money for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't follow your logic. What does his being nice to you have to do with him wanting Ordell's money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's setting me up to make a proposition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't propose something like that unless you're pretty sure the other person's into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. But I knew this narcotics cop one time. Told me that in a raid, the whole package never gets back to the station. His exact words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We weren't bullshittin' either, 'cause later he was suspended and forced to retire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has Nicolet told you any colorful stories like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No harm in that. He's a young guy havin' fun being a cop. I know the type, trust me on this. He's more interested in Ordell than the money. If he's gonna do anything suspect, it'll be cutting corners to get the conviction; but he wouldn't walk off with the money. It's evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? If I was in Nicolet's place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean you, right now. Not it you were somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I saw a way to walk off with a shopping bag full of money, would I take it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where it came from. It's not like it's anybody's life savings. It wouldn't even be missed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A half-a-million dollars will always be missed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, sure. I might be tempted. Especially now, since I'm getting out of the bail bonds business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie looks at him, "wow, that was a statement," but she doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to stand behind all my active bonds, but I'm not writing any new ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of reasons. But the main one would be I'm tired of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a long time coming. I finally made up my mind - I guess it was Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a date on it. Jackie's hand is signing her name. We WHIP UP and se her face, just as Max Cherry approaches her, handing her his business card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Max Cherry. Your bail bondsman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day you got me out of jail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that night I went to pick up a guy. I hear he's staying at this house, so I sneak in, wait for him to come home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. After we were together you went and snuck into a guy's house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max is dropping off Jackie at her apartment and saying goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max finding no gun in his glove box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Went to my office, found out you took my gun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max in his office, taking another pistol from his drawer, and a stun gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got another gun and a stun gun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And went to this guy's house in El Monte, and I waited for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do when he comes home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot him with the stun gun. While he's incapacitated, cuff him, take 'em to County.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you do it that night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never came home. But I'm sitting on the couch, in the dark, holding my stun gun and the whole house smells of mildew - So after a couple hours I think, "What am I doing here? Nineteen years of this shit? So I made up my mind, that's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie takes a pause before saying;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure you answered my question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you had a chance, unemployed now, to walk off with a half-million dollars, would you take it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe I said I'd be tempted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie smiles at him behind cigarette smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even think about it. You could get yourself killed go to prison...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I've figured a way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold for a few beats, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over this card, we hear an airplane landing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at work, standing at the exit of her plane. All the passengers are filtering out. She says goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye bye... Bye now... Goodbye Bye bye... Bye bye... Goodbye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, wearing her stewardess uniform, walks into the LAX parking structure, pulling her bad on wheels behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicolet and Dargus are waiting for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta stop meeting this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie smiles. They all fall in step towards Jackie's Honda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two cops and the black woman sit parked in her Honda. She, behind the wheel, Nicolet next to her in the passenger seat, Dargus in the backseat. Nicolet has the flight bag in his lap. He's taking out the manila envelope with the ten thousand inside. Their demeanor is very different from the first time they met. The three now almost act like friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet you're happy to be working again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is A.T.F. agent Ray Nicolet, Jackie Brown, Ordell Robbie money exchange trial run. It's three p.m., July 4th 1997. The location is the parking structure at LAX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pointing to a small mike on his lapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were going to let this one through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are. Don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every step of this goes in my report. (back to report voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am now taking a manila envelope from the subject's flight bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens it and takes out the ten thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The envelope contains currency... all the same denomination, one-hundred- dollar bills. Now, I'm counting it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time do you have to be there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four thirty. I'm meeting a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wouldn't say. You gonna follow her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves, somebody'll be on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're not going to stop her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicolet finishes counting, then hushes them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The envelope contains ten thousand dollars. The subject will be delivering the currency in a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Broadway shopping bag. A large bag with handles and brown lettering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Del Amo Mall on another lazy midday in the middle of the week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max rides up an escalator in the mall. He casually strolls through the mall, goes into a cappuccino bar called "BUSTA CAP" across from the food court. Walking up to the counter;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want whipped cream on that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max checks his watch: 4:30. He looks over at the food court and spots Jackie sitting at a table by herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie on the phone with Max, dressed for bed (long t- shirt and panties).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of it as money that shouldn't even be here. I mean does anybody have a right to it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max in his office on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It may be evidence once they get their hands on it, but right now it's only money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ponders his words as he watches her from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie sits at a table by herself, eating Japanese food from Teriyaki Donut and drinking an iced tea. As she eats she hears;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie looks up and sees a skinny YOUNG GIRL, black, quite pretty, no older than twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds a tray filled with tacos, enchiladas, rice and beans and a giant-sized Coke. She also has a Broadway shopping bag hanging from her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie looks at her tray of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would seem our Young Girl's from the South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put your bag on the floor, okay? Under the table, right next to mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Girl who hasn't looked right at Jackie since sitting down, bends sideways to glance under the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then when I leave, well, you know. What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... then back down at her tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheronda starts eating, head down, hunching close to the tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it bother you if I smoked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without raising her head, she shakes it from side to side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie takes out a pack of Davidoffs and lights one up with her yellow Bic. As she does this she observes Sheronda eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheronda, can I ask you a question? Are you and Ordell married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He say we like the same thing as married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheronda hesitates, then says without raising her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes every day, for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you don't see him for a few days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what's in the bag you're taking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Sheronda, it was nice talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie picks up Sheronda's bag and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max drinking his cafВЉ mocha sans whipped cream, watches Jackie leave the Young Girl and with Broadway bag in hand, walk out of the food court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max watches her walk down the mall when two young men in sport coats, jeans, and cowboy boots step out of a B. Dalton bookstore, stop her and begin talking. Knowing they must be Nicolet and Dargus, he watches one of them take the Broadway bag from Jackie and look inside. They talk for a minute - it would seem about nothing too serious. Jackie nods her head, listens to the two cops, nods her head again, and then walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he watches her walk away from the cops...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said it yourself. Ray wants Ordell, he don't give a shit about the money. Money won't convict him, guns will. Yeah, sure, if it falls in their lap, they take it. If they know they got it, they'll look for it... but if they don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max watches the two cops turn their attention to the young girl eating in the food court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max watches her, too. The Young Girl continues to work her way through her Mexican food, when she turns her head to an OLDER BLACK WOMAN sitting at the next table. The older woman says something, and the younger woman hands her the ashtray Jackie was using.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max watches the Young Girl finish her food and get up from the table. She stoops down to get the Broadway shopping bag and walks out of the food court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max watches Nicolet and Dargus let the Young Girl get a little ahead, then follow after her. They're gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max turns back on the older woman all alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finishes the coffee she was drinking and stands up, carrying - how about that? - A Broadway shopping bag. The woman heads out of the mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The older woman walks past us. She heads straight for the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks down a line of cars, then gets in a big, tan Mercury sedan. She drives of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but not before Max writes down her license plate number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you do to go through with the shit you start. You rationalize. I can do this, Max, I know I can. But I can't do it without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max climbs into his Seville, starts her up, and drives out of the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving down the street, lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could work... If she handles the cops right, I could work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hits 'play' on the dash CD player. The Delfonics fill the cab of the Caddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A garage door is lifted open, revealing Ordell and Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell and Louis are at Mr. Robbie's storage facility. A VAN is backed up nect to the opening. The facility is pitch black. Ordell ahs a big flashlight in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shines the beam into darkness. We see the facility is filled to the gills with machine guns, shotguns, uzis, a rocket launcher, and handguns of many types.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over half-million dollars worth of merchandise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell opens the back doors of the van. They start unloading machine guns and boxes of ammo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you about Melanie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She one of the women I got set up. I got Melanie in Hermosa Beach. I rent Simone a small house in Compton, and about four blocks away I got me this nineteen-year-old country girl named Sheronda. I found her waitin' for a bus two days outta Alabama, barefoot, country as a chicken coop. Took her to my house in Compton, told her it was Hollywood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, yeah. To her dumb country ass, Compton is Hollywood. Close as she's ever been, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this is about you fucked Melanie, I don't give a damn. I ain't a fool. I leave you alone with a bitch like Melanie, you're gonna be fuckin' that twenty minutes after I'm out the door. So say "thank you" and I'll tell you, "you're welcome."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I meant when I asked did you trust her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tryin' to work your ass against me, ain't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't even hafta say it. I know the woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why the fuck keep her around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause she my fine little surfer gal. She can't do me no harm. Fact she think she can play you against me shows how little she knows. You could teach that bitch for days how it is 'tween me an you, she never understand a damn word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you let someone know your business you can't trust?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't hafta trust her, I know her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't trust Melanie. But you can always trust Melanie to be Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't understand why you keep her around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She my fine little surfer gal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSEUP - Jackie's finger presses a small black button next to the handwritten name, "M. RALSTON."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bends down to talk in the speaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie walks down the hallway and finds the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens, she sees Melanie (for the first time) on the other side. Melanie, dressed in a t-shirt, cut offs, doesn't say a word - just turns around and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once Melanie leaves, she sees Ordell standing inside the apartment, screwdriver in hand, yelling after Melanie;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns his attention to Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees Louis (for the first time) sitting on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell says to Louis, but loud enough for Melanie in the other room to hear;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gonna hafta find her sandals... find her bag... find her sunglasses... take twenty damn minutes get her ass out the door. (to Jackie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie - his is Louis, Louis - Jackie. And the chick stompin' around in the other room is Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie comes out of the bedroom with her sunglasses, sandals, bag strung across her shoulders and her keys in her hand. She makes a bee-line towards the door without saying nothin' to nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a nice time, hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell looks to Jackie, raises his screwdriver and says;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to talk to you alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell and Jackie on the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want no more fuckin' surprises. We do this the way I laid it out, or we don't do it at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell you talkin' bout?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheronda passin' the money onto someone else, that's what the hell I'm talkin' 'bout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know she did that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was there, I saw her do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you weren't supposed to be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but I hung around, 'cause I figured you'd try an' pull some shit like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, hold on there. I ain't pullin' no shit. It's my money, I can do whatever the fuck I wanna do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not when it's my ass on the line you don't. We do this my way or fuck it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell tries to stop the hostile back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just chill the fuck out, Jackie. It ain't no big thing. The woman you saw was my friend, Simone. She's the one gonna be receiving the money, so I just wanted her to see how it works. She'll be here any minute. Nice woman, you'll like her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell opens the sliding glass and says to Louis in the living room;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, call Simone and tell her to get her tail over here. We're waitin' on her ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis gets up to make the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell turns back to Jackie and smiles, holding up his screwdriver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm about ready for a refill. Sure I can't tempt you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell and Jackie sit on stools around the kitchen counter/bar. Louis sits with them on the phone, silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicolet and Dargus stop me at the airport and mark the bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I don't like that part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It washes off. I tell them we're doing it the same way as before. They'll follow Sheronda. I hate the idea of leaving her for a fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She won't have no problems 'cause she don't know nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure she don' know about the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She don't know shit about the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does she think she's gettin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her this is a game us rich folks play, exchanging gifts. Like a scavenger hunt. She didn't know what that was neither. (to Louis)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang it up, she's on her way. You gotta listen to this. This involves you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis hangs up the phone and joins the debriefing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you gonna give her a Robinson's/May bag this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, the one Simone gives me. Simone and I'll make the switch at Robinson's/May. She knows what I look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She saw you with Sheronda. So Simone goes to the dress department with her Robinson's/May bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waits for you to go in the place where you try things on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fitting room. There's a sign over the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a hunch they'll be watchin' me. We can't risk switching bags out in the open or even in the dining area. That's why it has to be a woman, 'cause we do the switch in the fitting room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you come out with her Robinson's/May bag, go meet Sheronda. Simone peeks out, waits for my man Louis here to give her a signal nobody's watchin'. She leaves the store, gets in her car - mission accomplished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you gonna be during all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna be sittin' at the titty bar In downtown L.A. till my man over here calls me and gives me the O.K. sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie's pager goes off. She looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell walks Jackie to the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That works on my nerves, you bein' so buddy-buddy with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I wasn't, this wouldn't work. Now once I deliver I'll have to trust you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've been trusting you all this time, haven't I? We agreed on ten percent of what you bring in and that's what you gonna get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the elevator. She presses the button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a hundred thousand if I go to jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're partners, Baby, sorta. I ain't gonna screw you. You haven't told me where I put it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator arrives. Jackie steps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to the bail bondsman, Max Cherry. He'll take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max Cherry? You and him friends now? You tell him about this shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't know where the money came from. Only that it's money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the elevator shuts... As it shuts Ordell yells;...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you know all them bail bondsmen are crooks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't like the last piece of new information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Strand is the hip surfer street in downtown Hermosa Beach. Jackie leaves the apartment building. She walks to her car when she spots a funky little beach bar called, "Sally Leroy's."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally Leroy's is a beach bar with surfboards, different beer signs, and pictures of Marilyn Monroe, Elvis Presley, James Dean, Ann Margaret, and surfers riding monster waves all over the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JUKEBOX plays a loud seventies rock number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera picks Jackie up through the window, walking into the place and going up to the bar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A female bartender in her mid-twenties, wearing a plaid workshirt, named WANDA, goes to Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We follow with her to the back of the bar... the MUSIC is LOUD... the phone booth is occupied by a fat older GUY wearing surf clothes and sporting a mustache like a walrus. Jackie waits for him to finish his call... As she waits, the CAMERA MOVES BACK... until a blonde head of hair comes into the f.g....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA MOVES around to a CLOSEUP ON MELANIE, sucking on a beer, moving her head to the music, and watching Jackie. She smiles and steps OUT OF FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie turns and sees Melanie holding a beer, standing behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck. That guy's been in there since I got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I better look for another one, then. Thanks, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you and Ordell got goin'. You sit down and have a beer with me. I'll tell you a secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie looks at her a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coors, Sam, Rolling Rock, and Killian's Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better get me another Sam's. (to Jackie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Join me in a Jaeger shot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanda goes away. Jackie and Melanie sit at the bar. The MUSIC is LOUD, and they have to talk over it. Melanie moves her head to it during the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long you been with Ordell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time? Almost a year. I've known him forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you two fighting about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told me to go outside. (imitating Ordell's voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "You may leave us now." It's all part of his pathetic attempt to be "the man." You know Mr. Walker don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Walker's my buddy. Ask him about Ordell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That coke was yours, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie makes a face to show pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man, listen. I'm sorry about that. I hope they don't come down on you on my account. Ordell shoulda told you it was in your bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie digs in her purse for the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he didn't know about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe that? Yeah, well, I guess you have to trust him. (pulls out a ten)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd have second thoughts on that, but then I know 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie takes her Jaeger shot, lets it go down, then continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He killed a guy who works for him the other day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So tell me. Having all that money in your flight bag - Is it tempting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie nods 'yes', as she sips her beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you. If Ordell ever sent me to carry in ten thousand dollars, that would be the last motherfuckin' time he saw me. The next trip you're gonna have over half-a-million. If you thought of cutting Ordell out, I sure as hell wouldn't blame you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how easy it would be? He won't be anywhere near that mall. Pull one more switch, up front. That's it. half-a-million dollars. Need help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that fucker ever done for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so, but thanks for the beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and Nicolet sit at a steakhouse eating a steak dinner. Nicolet drinks beer, Jackie drinks white wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell has a white guy working for him named Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This afternoon before I came here. He was with Ordell at an apartment in Hermosa Beach. I don't know if he lives there, but I can find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His full name is Louis Gara. He just got out from serving four years in Susanville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bank robbery? Do you know what he does for Ordell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I imagine shit needs to be done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been following Mr. Gara, and he's definitely working for Ordell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a car, parked, on surveillance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis with the van, at the storage facility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They served two years together almost twenty years ago in Soledad. But he doesn't live in Hermosa Beach. Ordell's got him staying at a house in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The older woman in the mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Compton with a fifty-six-year- old petty thief - woman named Simone Hawkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever meet her, or they talk about her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White girl named Melanie Ralston. Another girlfriend of Ordell's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was her coke I got busted with. She knows everything, but she's not part of it, and she's pissed cause she's not part of it. Ordell wouldn't even let her stay at the meeting. She tried to talk me into ripping off Ordell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure that was the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I smiled and walked away. She also told me Ordell killed Beaumont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she mentioned Beaumont by name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this sounds like a lady I'd like to have a word with. So everything's set for tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Everything's the same, except one change...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max sits on the couch in Jackie's apartment drinking white wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie paces in front of him, white wine in one hand, Davidoff in the other, going over the details of tomorrow. One could notice a slight change in Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a bit of an edge to Miss Brown that's bubbling underneath her cool surface. It's understandable. After all, she's been the architect of this half-a-million dollars switcheroo. She's moved heaven and earth to make all the pieces fall into place, and all the players thnk what she wants them to think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she talks to Max she knows tomorrow all her hard work will either fail or succeed. But don't take this difference the wrong way. This edge I'm referring to is not one born out of fear (Jackie's nervous, but she's not afraid). It's more the edge an athlete might feel before an all-important competition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told them Ordell's changed the amount he's bringing in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think they bought it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. I got them thinking Ordell's real nervous. They love thinking he's scared of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, a good cop won't let you know he knows you're fulla shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All he needed was a reasonable explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Everything's the same except one change. Ordell thinks it's just too hot right now to bring in all his money. He knows you're watching him, and he's paranoid. He's keeping his stash where it is, but he wants to bring in fifty thousand for bail in case he needs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so literal. Ray believed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you still have to show him the money at the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know I'm not going to show him the whole amount. He'll see fifty thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't - I mean, he didn't the last time. He'll be expecting fifty thousand and there it is - on top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're takin' a helluva chance kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. If he finds it, I say Mr. Walker put the money in, and I didn't know nothing about it. Like the coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you're out and you get nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I'm not in jail and I tried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna have surveillance all over you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why you don't make a move till I come out of the fitting room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, a suit. There's one I had my eye on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSEUP - Ordell on the phone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Ordell. We got a bit of a change in plans here. Nothing to worry 'bout - everything's the same - except for one change. That bitch you saw in the mall, Simone. She wasn't here today, cause she split on me. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me an Louis went over to her place ,she's gone. She's gone and all her shit's gone and so's my ten thousand dollars. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't nothin' to worry about, girl. Everything's just like we discussed. Except when you do the switch, instead of Simone, it's gonna be Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie is lying on the couch, sprawled out like a cat. Louis sits at the other end of the couch. They're watching "Dirty Mary and Crazy Larry" on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Fonda and Susan George make jokes as they're pursued by police cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can hear Ordell on the phone. Melanie smiling at Louis, flirtatiously and conspiratorially lifts her bare foot and rubs his arm with it. Louis turns to her and gives her a look that says: "I'm not on your side, bitch. So knock it of."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie sees this and takes her foot away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis turns back to the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks at Louis for a moment, then sighs, saying under her breath;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Mexico and California on it. On the Mexico side we see "CABO SAN LUCAS" with a big circle around it. On the California side we see "LAX" in a similar circle. The tiny figure of a black AIRPLANE appears in the Cabo circle. With appropriate SOUND EFFECTS it takes off from Cabo, flying towards LAX, leaving a dotted line behind it. The CAMERA moves into a CLOSEUP of the little black airplane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rearranging her bag. The five hundred thousand inside takes up half the space. She tucks lingerie around the edges, covers the money with blouses, shoes, and skirts and ties I all down tight. Then places a fat envelope with fifty thousand right on top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie steps out of the bathroom, walks down the aisle, and is stopped by a PASSENGER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Miss, I'm waiting for a drink and you spend half the fuckin' flight in the can. Soon as we land I'm making a formal complaint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, because I called you an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't? Oh, well, you're an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie steps into the LAX parking structure, pulling her bag on wheels behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting for her is Ray Nicolet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to stop meeting like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fall into step towards her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said that the last time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's true, isn't it? After his is buttoned up we could meet someplace else. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could, if I'm not in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's taken care of. I called the State Attorney's Office. You were no-filed this morning in Circuit Court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This information stops Jackie in her tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying I'm off the hook?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicolet, who kept walking when Jackie stopped, looks back at Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free as a bird. I still expect you to finish the job, though. How much do you have this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty thousand, like I said. He's pretty sure he's gonna need it for bail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and Nicolet in the parked car. Ray has the flight bag in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees the clothes with the envelope on top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fifty thousand, huh? It doesn't look like that much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was told ten thousand in each pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never have. It's not my money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the envelope back in the bag and feels through the folds of a skirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He might have slipped some coke in here. Did you check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Walker promised he'd never do that again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicolet's fingers move to a pair of black heels wedged into the side... they touch the shoes... then move over to the envelope, opens the clasp and takes out five rubber-banded bond packets of loot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? To put one of these in my pocket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I did, I'd have to give you one, wouldn't I? Or we could take what we want. No one knows how much there is except us, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. All those things are true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all, it don't belong to nobody, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be one point of view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, it's not a point of view that A.T.F. shares. Once we make it evidence, it belongs to us. You are now officially out of trouble. Don't do nothing stupid, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I do anything if I'm being watched every second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you realize that. Saves me the trouble of pointing it out to you. (holding up the money)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put this in your shopping bag. It's what I expect to find when I look in Sheronda's. Comprende?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max Cherry sits behind his desk. WINSTON POWELL, the big black guy from the photo, is at the other desk on the phone. Max looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max stands up, takes the sport coat from the back of his chair, putsit on, and walks over to Winston's desk. Winston, still on the phone, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going out for a few hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to Del Amo, see a movie, get something to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever looks best and starts the soonest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston goes back to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max walks out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam's Hoffin Braur (German for beer garden) is a strip joint bar in downtown L.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell's on the pay phone. A STRIPPER strips in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you two still doing there?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis stands in the empty living room, talking to Ordell on the phone. Kate Bush plays in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was ready to leave ten minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordell snaps at Louis, not so harsh Louis is forced to retaliate, but enough to express his loss of patience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you the one in motherfuckin' charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she keeps saying 'in a minute.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go in there, snatch her by the hair, and drag her big ass out. This is my goddam money we're talking about. Get your ass out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, pissed at being hung up on and talked to like that, hangs up the phone and turns his frustration where it rightly belongs - Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis stomps towards the bedroom where the music's playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a montage of the individual characters in route to the mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In her Honda, smoking a cigarette, looking cool as usual, driving to the mall. Her car plays seventies soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his Cadillac Seville, cruising down Hawthorne Boulevard to the mall. He plays hid Delfonics CD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Melanie's Toyota drive towards the mall. Melanie drives singing along with Kate Bush on her car stereo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie's car pulls up to a lined parking space in the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie gets out of the Honda with her flight bag. She goes to her hatchback, takes a Robinson's/May bag, lines the first half of the bag with old paperbacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then takes out of the flight bag the envelope with the fifty-thousand marked dollars, takes one packet of ten thousand, and puts it in her pocket. She lines the envelope with forty thousand across the books, then fills the rest of the bag with beach towels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then with her flight bag slung over her shoulder, carrying the Robinson's/May bag and with all the confidence of a world champion prize fighter going into the ring, she strides toward the hugs mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie enters the mall. She looks at the people buzzing around. Any one of them could be surveillance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She calmly walks down the mall, then turns into the Roinson's/May store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, in her Cabo Air uniform, walks up to a young Asian saleswoman named Amy in the Robinson's/May designer clothing area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The saleswoman smiles when she sees Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you have a suit I've had my eye on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie steps out of the fitting room wearing a real sharp, badass, black suit with a white blouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God. You look so cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie moves over to the mirror, and checks herself out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This looks pretty good on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding, it looks great. You wear this to a business meeting, you're the badass in the room. But you can go out dancing in this too. It's a total power suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm gonna just get this for today. I'm in kind of a hurry. Would you mind ringing this up while I change out of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie walks into the fitting room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks down the fitting room hallway with changing cubicles on her right, enters the last one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes the door and sits down on the bench in between her flight bag full of money and the Robinson's/May bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A full-length mirror is straight I front of her. She looks at herself... when someone comes into the stall next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie's voice comes from the other side of the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you getting that black suit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you got something for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Robinson's/May bag, like Jackie's, filled with towels, comes sliding underneath the stall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie picks up her Robinson's/May bag, filled with books, towels and the marked forty-thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the loose packet of ten-thousand marked dollars and lies it on top of the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she does all this Melanie continues talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We coulda worked this. You know that, dontcha? You would've made out a lot better than you're going to, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie slides the Robinson's/May bag with money under the stall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie sees the money on top and stops talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
